Award.AwardTitle: Methods and Applications for Bilinear Operators
Award.AbstractNarration:
The subject matter of this project belongs to the realm of bilinear Fourier analysis. After the pioneering work of Joseph Fourier in the first decades of the nineteenth century, one is now familiar with the process of decomposing a signal or function into its elementary frequency components (analysis) as well as with the reverse process of superposing individual frequency components to form a single signal (synthesis). Fourier analysis thus acts in a way similar to a prism, which allows one to see the individual color components of a beam of light. Along these lines, when two functions or signals coexist, their frequency components interact and this phenomenon plays a key role in the study of certain partial differential equations that arise, for instance, in optics, quantum mechanics, and fluid dynamics. In the field of bilinear Fourier analysis, tools are developed to model the behavior and interaction of two signals by decomposing each one into their constituent frequencies, separating each decomposition into low and high frequencies, and studying the interplay between the low-low, high-low, and high-high frequencies from each decomposition. This project will also contribute to the integration of research and education at the postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate levels, to advancing discovery, to forming human resources, and to developing academic curricula.

Motivated by the study of commutators, bilinear Leibniz-type rules, paraproducts, and related topics in analysis and partial differential equations, the research activities of this project aim at developing methods in bilinear Fourier analysis to advance the theory of bilinear pseudo-differential operators and their applications. In particular, problems to be addressed include the description of the mapping properties, in the scales of Lebesgue, Besov, and Triebel-Lizorkin spaces, of bilinear pseudodifferential operators with symbols in certain critical classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The investigations associated to this project belong to the area of bilinear Fourier analysis and, more specifically, to various topics involving the study of bilinear pseudodifferential operators. Such objects combine two signals through a symbol that assigns different weights to the frequency components of the given signals; these operators play a crucial role in the understanding of solutions of   partial differential equations that arise, for instance, in optics, quantum mechanics, and fluid dynamics.

The outcomes of this project resulted in eight original research articles published in peer-reviewed journals that present novel aspects and continuity properties of bilinear pseudodifferential operators and related ones. The results obtained include, among others,  weighted Leibniz-type rules associated to bilinear pseudodifferential operators and their  applications to scattering properties of certain partial differential equations, boundedness properties of bilinear singular integrals and bilinear pseudodifferential operators with symbols in critical classes, and commutator estimates associated to partial differential equations in fluid dynamics. 

The project has contributed to the integration of research and education at the undergraduate and graduate levels. The PI supervised research projects for two undergraduate students and two PhD students, who were partially supported by this award; the PI's PhD students  completed their dissertation in topics related to the project and obtained academic positions.  The PI has taught topic courses in the area of Fourier Analysis at her institution and has disseminated the results of her work through numerous presentations at national and international conferences, invited talks in the US and abroad, and websites. The PI is a  co-organizer of  the Postdocs and Graduate Students Exchange Program, which gives a chance to advanced graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from KSU and neighboring universities to present their research in a friendly environment outside their departments, to interact with mathematicians in other universities, and to expand their professional networks.
